But since both players are identical in this setup—same initial money and same incentives—the Nash equilibrium would likely be symmetric. So if I give X dollars, they'll also give X dollars as a response? Or perhaps not necessarily, because my gain from them giving more depends on that.

Wait, if I give X dollars, then I have 10 - X, but the other player gets 3X. If they see that I gave away X, they might not give anything back because they can keep my 3X and still have their own 10. Wait no, if I give them X, they get 3X, so perhaps they will also give me Y dollars to get more.

Wait, if I consider that after both have made their decisions simultaneously and without knowing each other's choices, perhaps neither can benefit by changing their own strategy. So mutual giving might not occur because there's no reciprocity in a simultaneous move game.
